column1: Whole Person Physiome Table for Endocrine System

column26: Physiological Process

column1: List physiological functions as a hierarchy, starting with the body system in Function/1 (this should be the same as the table name), a major life function in Function/2, and more specific functions in subsequent columns. Add more columns if needed. Place limited explanatory text if needed in Function/Notes. Each function should include a ID from Gene Ontology (GO) if possible or another standard ontology. The LABEL column is the label for that ID as it appears in that ontology.
column26: Provide a very brief description (a few words) of the specific processes that occur during the corresponding function (e.g., a chemical reaction, physical change, feedback loop, etc.) in the Process column. Enter whether the Effector is a cell, tissue, or organ. Provide the anatomical location of the Effector in EffectorLocation along with the associated UBERON ID, if avaialble. Enter the Effector and its UBERON ID in the following columns. See Glossary for detailed instructions on tabulating the Signal, Effect, Behavior, Behavior X, Behavior Y, and X Target columns.
column41: Enter notes here from primary texts on quantitative information available for the processes denoted to the left
column42: Indicate the time scale category for this process: milliseconds, seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, years.
column43: Indicate the signal scale category for this process: autocrine, paracrine, intra-organ, circulatory, systemic
column44: Indicate the signal scale category for this process: autocrine, paracrine, intra-organ, circulatory, systemic
column45: OPTIONAL FOR NOW. List clinical measures, such as laboratory tests, vital signs, or radiology studies, related to the physiological function. These columns are simple lists and are NOT hierarchical. Include an ID for the measurement, such as a LOINC code, if known. Add more columns if needed.
column57: OPTIONAL FOR NOW. List other interacting physiological functions. These columns are simple lists and NOT hierarchical. Add more columns if needed. For the LABEL and ID columns, use Gene Ontology (GO) if possible.
column69: REQUIRED. Enter references in support of the information on this row. The ID column should include a standard identifier, such as a DOI or ISBN. The optional CHAPTER column should be used to list the relevant chapters in a book. The optional NOTES column can be used to clarify which part of the row the reference is for, such as a reference about the anatomical structures involved in the function rather than the interactions. Add more sets of reference columns if needed, making sure to include the ID column.

column26: Process
glucagon increases glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis in the liver to increase blood glucose; acts via adrenergic signaling
column41: units = pg/mL, Target is [80, 200] 2 hours after a mixed meal

column26: insulin promotes glycogen storage and glucose uptake; receptor tyrosin kinase; promotes translocation of GLUT4 in skeletal muscle and adipocytes
column41: units = µU/mL, Target is [50, 150] 2 hours after a mixed meal

column26: somatostatin is produced by delta cells to inhibit both glucagon and insulin secretion
pancreatic polypeptide reduces appetite and decreases gastric and pancreatic secretions
column41: units = pg/mL, typically increases by 200pg/mL after feeding

column26: c-peptide is a byproduct of insulin production, cleaved from pro-insulin
amylin slows gastric emptying and suppresses postprandial glucagon; co-secreted with insulin
column41: units = pmol/L, increased up to 25-30pmol/L post feeding

column26: aldosterone promotes sodium reuptake and potassium excretion in the distal convoluted tubule
column48: aldosterone/plasma renin activity ratio in plasma
aldosterone/plasma renin activity ratio in plasma

column26: cortisol increases gluconeogenesis and suppresses the immune system
column41: units = µg/dL, range is [5-25] in the morning, [0, 10] in the afternoon
units = mg/dL, Target is [100, 140] 2 hours after a mixed meal

column26: glycogen synthesis is increased in the fed state and decreased in the fasted state
glycogenolysis is increased by glucagon and in the fasted state
DHEA is a testosterone and estrogen precursor; elevated in adrenarche
column41: units = µg/dL, [44-332] for female, [89-457] for male

column26: epinephrine increases heart rate, blood pressure via alpha and beta adrenergic agonism; acts as neurotransmitter
norepinephrine increases vascular tone via alpha adrenergic agonism
modulates vascular tone and cardiac contractility via D1 and D2 receptors; involved in mood regulation
oxytocin is synthesized in the hypothalamus to promote milk ejection and uterine contraction
oxytocin is released from the posterior pituitary to promote milk ejection and uterine contraction
vasopressin is synthesized in the hypothalamus to promote fluid and sodium reabsorption
vasopressin is released from the posterior pituitary to promote fluid and sodium reabsorption
parvicellular neurons release somatostatin and dopamine to inhibit the anterior pituitary
CRH stimulates ACTH release from the anterior pituitary; released into hypophyseal portal circulation

column41: baseline ACTH increases 2-4x within 30-60 minutes of increased corticotropin releasing hormone

column26: GHRH simulates GH secretion from the anterior pituitary; released into hypophyseal portal circulation

column41: growth hormone peaks at approximately 10ng/mL or greater after GHRH stimulation

column26: TRH is secreted into hypophyseal portal circulation

column41: TRH increases TSH at least 5mU/L above baseline

column26: hypothalamic dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary via release into hypophyseal portal circulation
GnRH stimulates LH and FSH release from the anterior pituitary
column41: release of GnRH is sinusoidal, with period of 60-90 minutes
LH levels also sinusoidal, go from 10 to 40mU/mL in response to pulsatile GnRH

column26: LH triggers ovulation in females and testosterone production in males
column41: units = mU/mL, [1, 12] for female follicular phase, [9, 80] for mid-cycle peak, [2,9] for male

column26: ACTH stimulates adrenal cortisol and corticosteroid production

column7: development of secondary female sexual characteristics
column8: development of secondary female sexual characteristics
column26: prolactin promotes breast tissue development and lactation
GH stimulates growth, lipolysis, and hepatic IGF-1 production
FSH stimulates granulosa cells in females and Sertoli cells in males; FSH is released from the anterior pituitary in response to GnRH
column41: units = mU/mL, [2, 9] for female follicular phase, [4, 22] for female mid-cycle peak, [30, ] for post-menopausal female, [1, 7] for male

column26: TSH is produced by thyrotropes in the anterior pituitary
suprachiasmatic nucleus serves as the body's master clock regulator
SCN neurons integrate environmental light cues to synchronize circadian rhythm
melatonin promotes sleep and is secreted according to light/dark cycles
glucose sensing neurons in the hypothalamus regulate feeding and satiety
osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus regulate thirst and vasopressin release
thyroid epithelial cells produce T4; TPO oxidizes iodide to iodine, then attaches it to tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin to create MIT and DIT; two DIT molecules constitute T4
calcitonin lowers serum calcium by inhibiting bone resorption
deiodination of T4 generates T3, the active form of thyroid hormone (10% in thyroid)
column41: units = pg/mL, 10% of t3 is produced by the thyroid

column26: deiodination of T4 generates T3, the active form of thyroid hormone (90% in peripheral tissues)
column31: kidney proximal convoluted tubule epithelial cell
column32: kidney proximal convoluted tubule epithelial cell
column41: units = pg/mL, 90% of t3 is converted peripherally by liver, kidney, and skeletal muscle

column26: thyroglobulin is stored in colloid

PTH increases calcium and decreases phosphate by promoting reabsorption in the kidney, increasing bone resorption, increasing vitamin D activation, and increasing calcium uptake from the small intestine

column26: serves as a precursor to estrogen
column41: units = ng/dL, [30, 200] for female, [40, 150] for male

column26: converts androstenedione and testosterone to estrogen
column41: units = pg/mL, [10, 180] for female follicular phase, [100, 300] for female mid-cycle peak, [40, 200] for female luteal phase, [0, 10] for postmenopausal female, [20, 50] for male

column26: converts androstenedione and testosterone to estrogen
converts androstenedione and testosterone to estrogen
ghrelin is an orexigenic signal to the hypothalamus; stimulates growth hormone production
column41: units = pg/mL. increase feeding frequency if ghrelin is high

column26: leptin sends a satiety signal to the hypothalamus
column41: units = ng/mL, [0.7, 5.3] for males, [3.3, 18.3] for females, decrease feeding frequency if ghrelin is high

column26: glp-1 is an incretin hormone whose release is stimulated by feeding, then goes on to increase insulin secretion
column41: units = pg/L, [1.7, 5.1] for postfeeding, [1.5, 4.2] for fasting

column26: gip is produced in response to fats in the intestinal lumen; reduces stomach acid secretion directly via parietal cell inhibition and indirectly by inhibiting gastrin
gastrin increases gastric acid secretion; inhibited by prostaglandins and somatostatin
gastric acid is released in response to gastrin to aid in digestion by activating digestive enzymes such as trypsin and by solubilizing fats
gastric acid is released in response to gastrin to aid in digestion by activating digestive enzymes such as trypsin and by solubilizing fats
CCK stimulates gallbladder contraction and pancreatic enzyme release; slows gastric empyting
secretin stimulates HCO3- release from the duodenum and pancreas
column41: units = pg/mL, released into the blood when duodenal pH drops below 4

column26: motilin stimulates smooth muscle cell contraction in the esophageal sphincter, stomach, and duodenum
ANP triggers vasodilation of afferent arterioles to increase renal blood flow

column26: BNP triggers vasodilation and natriuresis in response to increased preload

column26: PGI2 triggers vasodilation and inhibits platelet aggregation
adiponectin increases insulin sensitivity and generally improves cardiovascular function; reduces steatosis via AMPK and PPARa pathways
resistin decreases insulin sensitivity and is elevated in type II diabetes
osteocalcin is produced by osteoblasts and indicates increased bone turnover
sclerostin is secreted by osteocytes and inhibits osteoblasts; antagonist of Wnt signaling
hepcidin is secreted by hepatocytes to lower iron levels by downregulating efflux via FPN1
igf-1 increases growth hormone signaling during sustained fed states
